heisig_chinese_memo: Pictograph of a rare sword with two massive blades.
heisig_story: Although this character no longer looks very much like a sword, it does have some resemblance to the handle of the sword. This is to our advantage, in that it helps us keep make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji.
koohiiStory1: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of ã‚« off in ã‚«ã‚¿ãƒŠ.
koohiiStory2: If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: The progression on this one is important. When you think "sword" you have to think, "What kinds of swords do Japanese people have?" Then you'll reach the meaning of this kanji on your own.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† (That's Tokyo!). ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã†.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine trying to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. I hope you don't have any other swords hidden anywhere.

origin_of_ch_char_book: The ancient Chinese kings used large animals for ceremonial sacrifices. The cow was one of the important animal sacrifices. (ç‰©, wu, thing) To the left of the character, there is a character which symbolizes the head of the cow (ç‰›, niu, cattle), to the right, there is a character which symbolizes the knife (åˆ€, dao, knife), and there are blood splattered (). This character depicts cutting a cow with a knife. Bronze Knife (13th-11th century BC) During the Shang (å•†) Dynasty (1600â€“1046 BC), the aristocrats sacrificed many animals for ceremonies. According to the records, the emperorâ€™s court also had many luxurious and grand ceremonies. At one occasion, hundreds of cows were sacrificed. Various sacrifices were offered other than cows at these ceremonies as well. So, (ç‰©, wu) changed its meaning from â€œsacrificeâ€ to â€œthings.â€,Since the sword is crucial in protecting oneself during battle, when the blade is broken, one may well be doomed. Having a strong blade is a matter of life and death. Here is a sword: (åˆ€, dao, sword). By contrast, (äº¡, wang, flee; lose) shows a sword whose blade is blunt or cut off. In other words, the sharp part of the blade was destroyed and became flat.,Bronze cow-shaped ceremonial bowl (16th century-11th century BC) The character (è§£, jie, separate) describes such works. It is composed of a man holding a horn of a cow (ç‰›, niu, cow), with a knife (åˆ€, dao, knife). Because it took a lot of strength and manpower, when aman had successfully done the work, he felt he had â€œsolvedâ€ a problem. Thus, now this character è§£ (jie) means not only â€œto separateâ€, but also â€œto solveâ€ or â€œto dissolveâ€.
humanum_full_description_en:
A gold inscription like a knife, an ancient weapon. The upper side is the blade, and the lower side is the knife handle. "Said Wen": "Swords, soldiers. Pictograms. All swords belong to the sword."

The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the name of the Fang country, "Compilation" 33035: "Xinhai Zhen, Wang Zheng (Zheng) Dao Fang." It means that the king conquered the knife country. Also used as place names and names.

Early inscriptions were used as clan names, and Warring States inscriptions were used as units of weight. Three-year pot: "Mound (weight) 474 knives (weight)". Eight years: "Mound (heavy) of the seventy swords (heavy)".

In the handed down literature, " sword " is used as " boat " to mean small boat, and " boat " is added after this meaning as "èˆ ". "poetry. Wei Feng. "Heguang": "Who is Heguang? There was no room for swords." Zheng Xuanjian: "The boat is called a sword."

In addition, " sword " originally has the sound of " Diao ", which means that the " Diao " of the surname was also expressed with " sword " at first, but later changed the word " sword " into a slap, and differentiated into the word " Diao " (Wang Mingsheng, Qiu Xigui ).

" Knife " is a kind of metal coinage in the pre-Qin period, and its shape evolved from a bronze tool knife. (See Huang Xiquan) Such as "Xunzi. "Honor and Disgrace" "Yu Daobu", Yang Chi's note: "Knives and cloth are money." "Historical Records. Leveling Book": "Agricultural, industrial and commercial transactions are open, and the coins of the turtle shell money knife cloth are prosperous." See " cloth ".

origin_of_ch_char_book: The ancient Chinese kings used large animals for ceremonial sacrifices. The cow was one of the important animal sacrifices. (ç‰©, wu, thing) To the left of the character, there is a character which symbolizes the head of the cow (ç‰›, niu, cattle), to the right, there is a character which symbolizes the knife (åˆ€, dao, knife), and there are blood splattered (). This character depicts cutting a cow with a knife. Bronze Knife (13th-11th century BC)During the Shang (å•†) Dynasty (1600â€“1046 BC), the aristocrats sacrificed many animals for ceremonies. According to the records, the emperorâ€™s court also had many luxurious and grand ceremonies. At one occasion, hundreds of cows were sacrificed. Various sacrifices were offered other than cows at these ceremonies as well. So, (ç‰©, wu) changed its meaning from â€œsacrificeâ€ to â€œthings.â€,Since the sword is crucial in protecting oneself during battle, when the blade is broken, one may well be doomed. Having a strong blade is a matter of life and death. Here is a sword: (åˆ€, dao, sword). By contrast, (äº¡, wang, flee; lose) shows a sword whose blade is blunt or cut off. In other words, the sharp part of the blade was destroyed and became flat.,Bronze cow-shaped ceremonial bowl (16th century-11th century BC)The character (è§£, jie, separate) describes such works. It is composed of a man holding a horn of a cow (ç‰›, niu, cow), with a knife (åˆ€, dao, knife). Because it took a lot of strength and manpower, when aman had successfully done the work, he felt he had â€œsolvedâ€ a problem. Thus, now this character è§£ (jie) means not only â€œto separateâ€, but also â€œto solveâ€ or â€œto dissolveâ€.

A gold inscription like a knife, an ancient weapon. The upper side is the blade, and the lower side is the knife handle. "Said Wen": "Swords, soldiers. Pictograms. All swords belong to the sword." The oracle bone inscriptions are used as the name of the Fang country, "Compilation" 33035: "Xinhai Zhen, Wang Zheng (Zheng) Dao Fang." It means that the king conquered the knife country. Also used as place names and names. Early inscriptions were used as clan names, and Warring States inscriptions were used as units of weight. Three-year pot: "Mound (weight) 474 knives (weight)". Eight years: "Mound (heavy) of the seventy swords (heavy)". In the handed down literature, " sword" is used as " boat" to mean small boat, and " boat" is added after this meaning as " èˆ ". "poetry. Wei Feng. "Heguang": "Who is Heguang? There was no room for swords." Zheng Xuanjian: "The boat is called a sword." In addition, " sword" originally has the sound of " Diao", which means that the " Diao" of the surname was also expressed with " sword" at first, but later changed the word " sword" into a slap, and differentiated into the word " Diao" (Wang Mingsheng, Qiu Xigui ). " Knife" is a kind of metal coinage in the pre-Qin period, and its shape evolved from a bronze tool knife. (See Huang Xiquan) Such as "Xunzi. "Honor and Disgrace" "Yu Daobu", Yang Chi's note: "Knives and cloth are money." "Historical Records. Leveling Book": "Agricultural, industrial and commercial transactions are open, and the coins of the turtle shell money knife cloth are prosperous." See " cloth".

Radicals: åˆ€  (sword)
Meaning Mnemonic
The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
The progression on this one is important. When you think "sword" you have to think, "What kinds of swords do Japanese people have?" Then you'll reach the meaning of this kanji on your own.
Reading Mnemonic
So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† (That's Tokyo!). ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã†.
Imagine trying to travel to ã¨ã†ãã‚‡ã† with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. I hope you don't have any other swords hidden anywhere.
